description: {"blocks":[{"key":"fgp6m","text":"This protocol describes the process of nucleofection of sgRNA in PX458 plasmid into a mouse cancer cell line and subsequent flow sorting of single cells based on GFP fluorescence.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: I use this protocol and it’s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8rja5","text":"Following sgRNA cloning into PX458 plasmid (Cas9-2A-GFP), the plasmid can be introduced into the cells by nucleofection. I use Nucleofector 2b device.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"at1vo","text":"Trypsinise cells on 70-90% 10 cm plate. Count and spin down 1.5-2 x 10^6 cells per reaction (3 min, 1200 rpm). Switch on the Nucleofector device and set to the predetermined programme. Make sure to plate some spare cells in a separate plate to use as an ‘unstained control’ for FACS later","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"am7g8","text":"Prepare Nucleofector solution (82 uL of nucleofection solution + 18 uL of supplement per reaction). Keep at RT.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7dsjq","text":"Transfer the cell/DNA suspension into the bottom of the cuvette (without air bubbles). Close the cap","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"309ok","text":"Add DNA to the prepared mix (2.5 ug per reaction). Use highly-concentrated DNA prep. Try not to exceed 120 uL total reaction volume","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6t4pq","text":"Add Nucleofection solution with DNA to each pellet individually and mix gently. Avoid leaving the cells in the nucleofection solution for too long","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6c0fs","text":"Use program T-030 (for PDA530Met cells). This was determined by using Nucleofection optimisation kit. It would require an optimisation step to determine optimal conditions for another cell line. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4riao","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bhijv","text":"Insert cuvette with cell/DNA suspension into holder and apply the selected programme","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fhhi2","text":"After nucleofection, add 500 uL of complete medium to the cuvette and gently transfer the sample to a 10 cm dish using supplied pipettes. Top up with warm medium","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"40t0p","text":"Flow sort 24 h later (48 h after nucleofection). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"519sj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"acfio","text":"FACS sorting details: Use 100 um nozzle, add Hoechst or DAPI (1-10 ug/mL final) to the samples and have an unstained control and Hoechst only. Take an aliquot of nucleofected cells to use as a GFP-only single stain control. Aliquot 200 uL media into 96-well plates and keep warm in the incubator. Prepare 3-4 plates per sample (this will depend on the viability of each cell line after the sort, but is generally a good starting point). I usually get 15-30 single-cell clones per plate. Sort single live GFP+ cells into the wells. Also sort 100 or more cells into one well to use as a polyclonal population and a control of viability after the sort. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fuq19","text":"The presence of GFP at flow sort does not necessarily mean successful editing. The polyclonal population might contain unedited wild-type cells.  I tend to use single-cell KO clones, but that carries a risk of clonal heterogeneity, so would need testing multiple clones. Some papers derive single cell clones, confirm the presence of a KO, and then pool 4-5 of these clones to use as a polyclonal population in-vivo.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7fr7k","text":"I use non-edited clones as controls, but you can also make a separate non-targeting sgRNA control. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fu0rb","text":"It is good to check for any GFP expression after the clones are expanded, just to confirm no genomic integration of the plasmid has taken place. I haven’t seen that given there is no selection involved in the process, and the transiently-nucleofected plasmid is lost over time.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
